subject: FAITH AND ENDURANCE
verse: Dear brothers and sisters, whenever trouble  comes your way, let it be an opportunity for  joy.—for when your faith is tested, your endur- ance has a chance to grow. (James 1:2-3)
reflection: James does not say if trouble comes our way but whenever it does, he assumes that we will have troubles and that it is possible to profit from them. The point is not to pretend to be happy when we face pain but to have a posit- ive outlook (“let it be an opportunity for joy”) because of what troubles can produce in our life. James tells us to turn our hardships into times of learning. YES, tough times can teach us perseverance.
prayer: Ask the Lord to teach you greater patience during trials.

subject: ACCEPTING TRIALS
verse: Let your endurance grow, for when it is fully developed, you will be strong in character and  ready for anything. (James 1:4)
reflection:
We can not really know the depth of our character until we see how we react under pressure. It is easy to be kind to others when everything is going well, but can we still be kind when others are treating us unfairly? Remember
God wants to make us mature and complete, not to keep us from all pain. Instead of com- plaining about our struggles, we should see them as opportunities for growth. Remember Also, God promises not to leave us alone with our troubles, He promises to stay close and help us grow.
prayer: Thank God for promising to be with you in rough times. Ask Him to help you solve your problems or give you strength to endure them. Then be patient!

reflection: Wisdom means “practical discernment.” It begins with respect for God—leads to right living—and results in increased ability to tell right from wrong. prayer: Ask Him to stabilize your wavering or doubtful mind, then commit yourself whole-heartedly to Him. . . .

verse:

reflection:
The poor should be glad because riches mean nothing to God, otherwise these people would be considered unworthy. The rich should be glad that money means nothing to God because money is easily lost. not in what is temporary [our money and possessions] read (Mark 4:18-19) for Jesus words on this subject.
prayer: Ask the Lord to help you treat others as He would.

subject: LET US EXAMINE OUR DESIRES
verse:
Remember, no one who wants to do wrong should ever say, “God is tempting me.” God is never tempted to do wrong, and He never tempts any-  one else either.
Temptation  comes from the lure  of our own desires. (James 1:13-14)
reflection:
People who live for God often wonder why they still have temptations.
Does God tempt them? Heavens No! God tests people, but He does not tempt them by trying to seduce them to sin. God allows Satan to tempt people, however, this is done to refine their faith and help them grow in their dependence on Christ. We can only resist the temptation to sin by turning to God for strength and choosing to obey His Word.
The problem today is people often ruin their lives by their own fool-ishness and then are angry at the Lord.
prayer: Let us place all our desires in God’s hands for His approval.

prayer: Let us remember to talk less and listen more!

subject: REMEMBERING WHAT YOU HEARD
verse: If you keep looking steadily into God’s perfect  law—the law that sets you free—and if you do  what it says and don’t forget what you heard,  then God will bless you for doing it.  (James 1:25)
reflection: It seems contradictory that a law could give us freedom, but God’s law points out sin in us and gives us the opportuneity to ask for God’s for-giveness (read Romans 7:7, 8). As Christians, we are saved by God’s grace, and salvation frees us from sin’s control. As believers, we are free to live as God created us to live. Of course, this does not mean that we are free to do as we please (read I Peter 2:16). We are now free to obey God.
prayer: Let us always look to Jesus for our salvation.

subject: PUTTING GOD'S WORD INTO PRACTICE
verse: Pure and lasting religion in the sight of God our Father, means that we must care for orphans and widows in their troubles, and refuse to let the  world corrupt us. (James 1:27)
reflection:
In the first century, orphans and widows had very little means of economical support. Unless a family member was willing to care for them, they were reduced to begging, selling themselves as slaves, or starving. By caring for these people, the church puts God’s Word into practice.
When we give with no thought of receiving, we show what it means to truly serve others.
prayer: True faith means nothing if we adapt to the world’s values.

subject: GENUINE FAITH
verse: My dear brothers and sisters, how can you claim  to have true faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ  if you favor some people more than others?  (James 2:1)
reflection:
James condemns acts of favoritism. Often we treat people who are better off, then we do those who are poor. I’m afraid we often do this because we would rather be identified with successful people than with apparent failures. James reminds
us that the supposed winners may have gained their impressive lifestyle at our expense. We may also notice that the rich often find it hard to ident- ify with the Lord Jesus, who came as a humble
servant.
Are you easily impressed by status, wealth, or fame? Are you partial with the “have” while ignoring the “have nots”? This attitude is sinful. God views all people as equals, And IF
He favors anyone, it is the poor and powerless…
prayer: We should follow Christ's example.

subject: MERCY WHERE MERCY IS SHOWN
verse:
Whenever you speak, or whatever you do,  remember you will be judged by the law of love,  the law that sets you free.
For there will be no  mercy for you if you have not been merciful to  others. But if you have been merciful, then  God’s mercy toward you will win out over His judgement against you. (James 2:12-13)
reflection: Only God in His mercy can forgive our sins. We need to remember that we can not earn forgiveness simply by forgiving others. prayer: It is important to listen to what God’s Word says, but it is much more important to obey it and do what it says.

subject: WHAT DO YOUR DEEDS DISPLAY?
verse: Now some argue, “Some people have faith,  others have good deeds.” I say , I can not  see your faith if you do not have good deeds,  but I will show you my faith through my good  deeds. (James 2:18)
reflection:
At first glance, this verse seems to contradict Romans 3:28,
“We are made right with God through faith and not by obeying to law.” Deeper invest- igation, however, shows the teaching of James and Paul are not at odds with one another. While it is true that our good deeds can never earn us salvation, true faith always results in a changed life and good deeds. Paul speaks against those who try to be saved by deeds instead of true faith; James speaks against those who confess mere intellectual assent with true faith. After all, demons know who Jesus is, but they
do not obey Him (James 2:19).
prayer: True faith involves a commitment of your whole self to God.

Are you tempted to escalate the conflict, pass on gossip, or fan the fire of discord?
Careful, winsome speech and wise, loving words are the seeds of peace makers.
prayer: Remember genuine wisdom comes from God.

prayer: Remember, pleasure that keeps us from pleasing God is sinful; pleasure from God’s rich bounty is good.

subject: JUDGE NOT LEST YE BE JUDGED
verse: Don’t speak evil against each other, my dear brothers and sisters. If you criticize each other and condemn each other, then you are criticizing and condemning God’s law. But you are not a judge who can decide whether the law isright or wrong. Your job is to obey it. (James 4:11)
reflection: Jesus summarizes the law as love for God and neighbor (Matthew 22:37-40), and Paul said that love demonstrated toward your neighbor would fully satisfy the law (Romans 13:6-10). When we fail to love, we are actually breaking God’s law. Take time to examine your attitude and actions toward others. Do you build people up or do you tear them down. When you are ready to criticize someone, remember God’s law of love and say something good instead. Saying something benef- icial to others will cure you of finding fault; and increase your ability to obey God’s Law of love.
prayer: God alone has the power to save or destroy. So what right do we have to condemn our neighbor?
